newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Privatisation plans could divide Bosnia - Silajdzic.
newsitem.headline: Privatisation plans could divide Bosnia - Silajdzic.

text.p: Bosnia's Moslem-Croat federation and Serb republic are drawing up separate privatisation laws that directly undermine the unity of the country, the Bosnian co-prime minister said in an interview.

Haris Silajdzic, the central government's Moslem co-chairman, said the state of Bosnia-Hercegovina, not its two entities, should inherit the assets of Yugoslavia's former republic and therefore, regulate privatisation.

Bosnia emerged from a 43-month war as one country but was effectively split into two territories that include a Moslem-Croat federation spread over 51 percent of the territory and a Serb republic controlling the rest.

The country has a small central government consisting of a cabinet, parliament and a three-man presidency comprised of Moslems, Serbs and Croats. But diplomats say the joint institutions have been virtually paralysed because Serb representatives remain opposed to a unified state.
How the privatisation issue is resolved could determine whether Bosnia survives as a single state or permanently divides into Serb and Moslem-Croat territories, Silajdzic said.
"If the entities are in charge of this (privatisation), it would lead us to have two incompatible economic systems and eventually, the dissolution of Bosnia-Hercegovina."
Bosnian Serb authorities say they have the right to pursue their own privatisation programme.
And officials from the Moslem-Croat federation argue it is better to press ahead rather than wait for the inter-ethnic central government to work out an agreement.
Haggling between federation and Serb officials would waste valuable time and delay possible foreign investment, they say.

"It would be good to have a state privatisation law, but there is no chance to adopt it at the central level right now," former federation prime minister, Hasan Muratovic told a Sarajevo newspaper last week.
But Silajdzic said "does such a hasty decision solve anything or create long-term economic chaos?"

The International Crisis Group (ICG), a private agency monitoring the peace process, supported Silajdzic's views in an analysis of the succession issue. ICG based its conclusions on international law and recent practices applied afer the break-up of the former Czechoslavia and Soviet Union.
Only states, not autonomous provinces, posess the necessary capacity to succeed the rights and obligations of the predecessor state, ICG said in a report issued two days ago.

Separate legislation could create a legal morass for foreign investors, damage Bosnian companies with assets in both entities and open the way to nationalist discrimination against property owners, Silajdzic said.
"Only the state of Bosnia-Hercegovina can regulate this (foreign capital) according to our constitution and not the entities. Who in the outside world would want to deal with two systems?" he said.
Silajdzic proposed a compromise solution that outlines basic principles for privatisation, restitution and ownership and offered it to the entities. But so far, they have refused to budge, he said.
The international High Represenative to Bosnia, Carl Bildt, may ultimately settle the issue.
For Silajdzic, the dispute goes to the heart of the 1995 peace treaty, which called for preserving Bosnia as a single state. "If that is the wish here, then why did we insist on a unified state?"
